instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.A1398: What is A1398? A1398 is a model number for a 15 inch size MacBook Pro Retina from years Mid 2015, Mid 2012, Early 2013, Late 2013, Mid 2014 with EMC 2909, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-00138, 820-00163, 820-00426, 820-3332, 820-3662, 820-3787..
definitions.820-3332: What is 820-3332? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PP5V_S5: What is PP5V_S5? This is a 5v power rail that is present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state..
definitions.3V3_SUS: What is 3V3_SUS? 3V3_SUS is an abbreviation for PP3V3_SUS. These are interchangeable. The "PP3V3_SUS" rail on a MacBook logic board is a power rail that provides a 3.3-volt supply to the suspend-to-RAM (S3 state) components. .
definitions.PM_SLP_S4_L: What is PM_SLP_S4_L? PM_SLP_S4_L is a signal that puts the system into an S4 suspend to disk sleep state when it is low(_L means signal is asserted when voltage is low).
definitions.SMC_ONOFF_L: What is SMC_ONOFF_L? SMC_ONOFF_L tells the computer that the power button has been pressed when it is low, _L means signal is asserted when it is low voltage. .
definitions.PM_PWRBTN_L: What is PM_PWRBTN_L? PM_PWRBTN_L refers to the power button signal line. This line is used to initiate the power-on sequence of the laptop. The "L" at the end of "PM_PWRBTN_L" suggests that it is an active-low signal, meaning that when the power button is pressed, the signal is pulled low to initiate the boot sequence..

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power
threads.message:
Hi,

I have an <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A that has no power.
I have green light, no fan spin and it pulls 0.10A  from bench PSU.
No voltages on big coils.

<SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> = 5V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> = 3.3V
<SIGNAL>PP5V_SUS</SIGNAL> = 0V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S3</SIGNAL> = 0V

Can you help?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power
threads.message:
Any history available?
Do you get <SIGNAL>3V3_SUS</SIGNAL>?

Be aware, this board requires 85W charger to turn on, without battery.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power
threads.message:
Hi,
No history. Stoped working overnight. I saw a bit of corrosion oc <CAPACITOR>C5856</CAPACITOR> (not shorted), but everithing seams ok besides that.
I don't get  <SIGNAL>3V3_SUS</SIGNAL> (0V).

Even with the board on bench PSU, it doesn't power on (with or without battery).

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power
threads.message:
Trigger <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> and check for drop pulse at <SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL>.
If detected, check for pulse at <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL>, at same time.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power
threads.message:
Hi,
I don't get a drop pulse on  <SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL> when trigering  <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL>. It stays steady at 0.333V.
On <CHIP>U5010</CHIP> i get 3.4V on <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL>

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power
threads.message:
"It stays steady at 0.333V"
Of course, impossible to drop from 0V to 0V.
Must find why <SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL> stays always low; should stay at 3V.
Check <RESISTOR>R1985</RESISTOR>...

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power
threads.message:
Hi,

While measuring <RESISTOR>R1985</RESISTOR> after a few days, (witch is ok btw with 1kohm), the mac started to power on, and now I get 3.3V on  <SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL>...

Everithing seams to be working ok. What shal I check to make sure that everithing is OK?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power
